merger_name: Stockland LLC – intragroup transfer of Halcyon Jardin and Evergreen projects

acquirers.name: SMLLP ASSET PTY LTD (as trustee for the SMLLP Evergreen Trust)
SMLLP SUB PTY LTD (as trustee of the SMLLP Development Sub Trust)

targets.name: STOCKLAND LAND LEASE MANAGEMENT PTY LIMITED
Stockland LLC No. 2 Pty Ltd (as trustee for the Stockland LLC St Germain Trust)

merger_description:
As part of its activities, Stockland Corporation Ltd and Stockland Trust (**Stockland**) operates a land lease communities (**LLC**) business, which currently comprises a portfolio of 39 LLC projects nationally, including both established communities and communities under development/in planning.

Stockland proposes, as a restructure, to transfer the land and development assets from two Stockland LLC projects, Halcyon Jardin and Halcyon Evergreen (in Clyde and Clyde North in Victoria), from Stockland controlled trusts/entities to newly established special purpose trusts (the **Acquisition**):

* The Jardin and Evergreen land will be transferred to SMLLP Asset Pty Ltd as trustee for the SMLLP Jardin Trust (**Jardin Land Buyer**) and SMLLP Asset Pty Ltd as trustee for the SMLLP Evergreen Trust (**Evergreen Land Buyer**) respectively.
* The Jardin and Evergreen development rights will be granted and development 'work in progress' will be transferred to SMLLP Sub Pty Ltd as trustee of the SMLLP Development Sub Trust (**Development Buyer**).

At the time of the Acquisition, the Jardin Land Buyer, Evergreen Land Buyer and Development Buyer will be (indirectly) controlled by Stockland. As newly established trusts, the Jardin and Evergreen Land Buyers and Development Buyer have no existing activities. Stockland will, post transfers, continue to develop the Jardin and Evergreen projects.

events.title: Notification waiver determination published
events.determination_commission_division: Determination made by Commissioner Woodward pursuant to a delegation under section 25(1) of the Act

determination_table_content.details:
Stockland Corporation Ltd and Stockland Trust (together Stockland)
applied for a notification waiver in respect of SMLLP Asset Pty Ltd’s
and SMLLP Sub Pty Ltd (Stockland Buyers) proposed acquisition of
the land and development rights of the Halcyon Jardin and Halcyon
Evergreen projects, currently held by Stockland LLC No.2 Pty Ltd and
Stockland Land Lease Management Pty Limited (Stockland Sellers),
as described in the transaction documents provided as part of the
application (the Acquisition).

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission has
determined under section 51ABV(1)(a) of the Competition and
Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) that the Acquisition is not required to be
notified.

The acquirer, Stockland, operates a land lease communities (LLC)
business, which currently comprises a portfolio of 39 LLC projects
nationally, including both established communities and communities
under development/in planning.
The Stockland Buyers are newly established trusts which will be
(indirectly) controlled by Stockland.
The Stockland Sellers are entities indirectly, wholly owned by
Stockland.

In making this notification waiver determination, the Australian
Competition and Consumer Commission (the ACCC) has considered
the information provided with the notification waiver application and
had regard to the factors in section 51ABV(2)(b) of the Competition
and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) (the Act).
Based on the information provided in the application, the ACCC
considers that the Acquisition is unlikely to give rise to any material
lessening of competition. In particular:
a. The Acquisition involves the transfer of assets between
Stockland-controlled entities.
b. There is no horizontal consolidation or removal of a
competitor as a result of the Acquisition.
Given the above considerations that material competition concerns
are unlikely to arise, the ACCC has determined that the Acquisition is
not required to be notified.
In these circumstances, the ACCC does not consider it necessary to
reach a concluded view on the likelihood of the notification
thresholds being met.
The ACCC considers that the determination is consistent with the
object of the Act and the interests of consumers in promoting
competition.
The ACCC notes that it also considered the potential application of
section 51ABD (internal restructures and reorganisations) of the Act.
The application states that, on the facts of this matter, including the
particular entities and structures involved, it was not clear that the
Acquisition fell within that provision. Given this uncertainty, the
ACCC considered it appropriate to assess the notification waiver
application on the basis that the acquisition provisions in the Act
applied to the Acquisition.
For more information about the ACCC’s approach to considering
notification waiver applications and to assessing competition
effects more generally, see the ACCC’s interim guidance on
notification waivers and merger assessment guidelines.
